Here we found a Kd for αN1–22 binding to wild-type δ of 113 nm, slightly lower than the value of 130 nm reported in our previous work (17Weber J. Muharemagic A. Wilke-Mounts S. Senior A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 13623-13626Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), and for binding of αN1–22 to V79A δ we found a Kd of 1.95 μm compared with 2.4 μm in the previous report. Increasing the peptide length by two residues in αN1–24 reduced affinity of binding to wild-type δ by 43-fold. Reduction in length by two residues (αN1–20) also decreased affinity in wild-type δ, by 11-fold. Further reduction in length of the peptide yielded greater decreases in binding affinity, such that neither αN1–14 nor αN1–12 peptides showed measurable binding to wild-type δ subunit. The same general pattern of reduced affinity was seen for the series of peptides binding to V79A mutant δ. It may be noted that binding of the parent αN1–22 peptide to V79A δ is already 17-fold weaker than to wild-type δ. Overall, the data show that for optimal binding to δ, a peptide with a length of 22 residues is required, suggesting that residues located along the entire sequence make interactions with δ. Possibly, the two additional residues in αN1–24 cause formation of novel structure in the peptide or simply interfere with binding to δ by folding back on the rest of the peptide. Testing the Idea That the N-terminal Region of the α Subunit Forms an Amphipathic Helix and That Hydrophobic Residues on One Surface Make Interactions with δ Subunit—Fig. 1C shows a helical wheel diagram of residues α6–α19. A series of hydrophobic residues shown in italic type (Leu-11, Ile-8, Phe-19, Ile-12, and Ile-16) clusters on one surface of the helical wheel. (Arg-15 on this surface may also be viewed as potentially hydrophobic, depending on its orientation). Conversely, the other surface shows mainly polar residues (Ser-9, Lys-13, Thr-6, Glu-10, Gln-14, Glu-7, Gln-18). Given that we had identified helices 1 and 5 of δ as forming the F1-binding surface (15Weber J. Wilke-Mounts S. Senior A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 13409-13416Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) and that the NMR structure of δ shows these helices forming a hydrophobic groove (16Wilkens S. Dunn S.D. Chandler J. Dahlquist F.W. Capaldi R.A. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1997; 4: 197-201Crossref Scopus (110) Google Scholar), it seemed likely that some or all of the hydrophobic residues listed above might make direct interaction with δ. Furthermore, an analysis of sequences of α subunit from multiple species revealed that hydrophobic residues are strongly favored at positions α8, α11, α12, α16, and α19 (data not shown). Initially, we tested binding of peptides containing point mutations at position αIle-8 in αN1–22, namely αN1–22(I8E) and αN1–22(I8K), both containing a charged residue in place of Ile. Fig. 4 shows typical fluorescence titrations with wild-type and V79A mutant δ, and Table I shows the calculated Kd values. The substitutions Glu and Lys for Ile at residue 8 in αN1–22 peptide caused approximately equal losses of binding affinity with either wild-type or V79A mutant δ in the range of 5–8-fold. Therefore, it was clear that residue αIle-8 is important for binding of α to δ. In further work (Table II), we found that when the mutations αI8E and αI8K were incorporated into the uncA (α subunit gene) and expressed in E. coli cells, they caused reduction of growth yield in vivo, indicating loss of ATP synthesis capacity and reduction of ATPase activity and ATP-driven proton pumping in membrane preparations in vitro. The ATPase activity showed somewhat reduced DCCD inhibition. Experiments using NADH to induce proton pumping showed that none of these membrane preparations was leaky to protons (data not shown). In contrast, the mutations αI8A and αI8W (where hydrophobic residues are substituted for αIle-8) had much lesser effects on growth yield, membrane ATPase, and ATP-driven proton pumping (Table II). Fig. 5 shows fluorescence titrations with these peptides using wild-type δ. The calculated Kd values are given in Table I. Substitution of Glu at any one of these positions impaired binding impressively. Binding affinity was decreased at least 10-fold in all cases. Interestingly, the αN1–22(I16E) peptide brought about a quench of the fluorescence with wild-type δ rather than the usual fluorescence enhancement. Of 23 peptides tested in this and other work, this was the only peptide with this property, suggesting that residue αIle-16 may come very close to residue δTrp-28 when α is bound to δ. We also tested binding of the same series of point mutant peptides to V79A mutant δ (titrations not shown), and resultant calculated Kd values are listed in Table I. A similar pattern of reduction of binding affinity was apparent. It may be noted that a fluorescence quench was again seen when αN1–22(I16E) was titrated with V79A mutant δ; however, the fluorescence changes were too small to permit confident calculation of Kd values. The functional importance of the N-terminal epidermal growth factor-like domain (EGF-N) of factor X/Xa (FX/Xa) was investigated by constructing an FX mutant in which the exon coding for EGF-N was deleted from FX cDNA. Following expression and purification to homogeneity, the mutant was characterized with respect to its ability to function as a zymogen for either the factor VIIa-tissue factor complex or the factor IXa-factor VIIIa complex and then to function as an enzyme in the prothrombinase complex to catalyze the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin. It was discovered that EGF-N is essential for the recognition and efficient activation of FX by both activators in the presence of the cofactors. On the other hand, the FXa mutant interacted with factor Va with a normal apparent dissociation constant and activated prothrombin with ∼3-fold lower catalytic efficiency in the prothrombinase complex. Surprisingly, the mutant activated prothrombin with ∼12-fold better catalytic efficiency than wild-type FXa in the absence of factor Va. The mutant was inactive in both prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time assays; however, it exhibited a similar specific activity in a one-stage FXa clotting assay. These results suggest that EGF-N of FX is required for the cofactor-dependent zymogen activation by both physiological activators, but it plays no apparent role in FXa recognition of the cofactor in the prothrombinase complex. The functional importance of the N-terminal epidermal growth factor-like domain (EGF-N) of factor X/Xa (FX/Xa) was investigated by constructing an FX mutant in which the exon coding for EGF-N was deleted from FX cDNA. Following expression and purification to homogeneity, the mutant was characterized with respect to its ability to function as a zymogen for either the factor VIIa-tissue factor complex or the factor IXa-factor VIIIa complex and then to function as an enzyme in the prothrombinase complex to catalyze the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin. It was discovered that EGF-N is essential for the recognition and efficient activation of FX by both activators in the presence of the cofactors. On the other hand, the FXa mutant interacted with factor Va with a normal apparent dissociation constant and activated prothrombin with ∼3-fold lower catalytic efficiency in the prothrombinase complex. Surprisingly, the mutant activated prothrombin with ∼12-fold better catalytic efficiency than wild-type FXa in the absence of factor Va. The mutant was inactive in both prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time assays; however, it exhibited a similar specific activity in a one-stage FXa clotting assay. These results suggest that EGF-N of FX is required for the cofactor-dependent zymogen activation by both physiological activators, but it plays no apparent role in FXa recognition of the cofactor in the prothrombinase complex. Factor X (FX) 1The abbreviations used are: FX, factor X; FXa, activated factor X; EGF, epidermal growth factor; FX-desEGF-N, factor X mutant in which the N-terminal epidermal growth factor-like domain has been deleted by recombinant DNA methods; Gla, γ-carboxyglutamic acid; TF, tissue factor; sTF, soluble tissue factor; dcTF, tissue factor in which the cytoplasmic domain has been deleted by recombinant DNA methods; SpFXa, Spectrozyme FXa; PC, phosphatidylcholine; PS, phosphatidylserine; PT, prothrombin time; aPTT, activated partial thromboplastin time; RVV, Russell's viper venom. is a multidomain vitamin K-dependent plasma serine protease zymogen that, upon activation to factor Xa (FXa), assembles into the prothrombinase complex (factor Xa, factor Va, negatively charged membrane surface and Ca2+ ion) to convert prothrombin to thrombin in the final phase of the blood coagulation cascade (1Nesheim M.E. Kettner C. Shaw E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 6537-6540Google Scholar, 2Rosing J. Tans G. Govers-Riemslag J.W.P. Zwaal R.F.A. Hemker H.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 274-283Google Scholar, 3Furie B. Furie B.C. Cell. 1988; 53: 505-518Google Scholar, 4Davie E.W. Fujikawa K. Kisiel W. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 10363-10370Google Scholar, 5Jackson C.M. Nemerson Y. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1980; 49: 765-811Google Scholar). FX circulates in plasma as an inactive two-chain zymogen in which the noncatalytic light chain is linked to its catalytic heavy chain by a single disulfide bond (6Leytus S.P. Foster D.C. Kurachi K. Davie E.W. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 5098-5102Google Scholar, 7Stenflo J. Blood. 1991; 78: 1637-1651Google Scholar). Similar to most other vitamin K-dependent coagulation protease zymogens, the structure of the N-terminal light chain of FX is composed of a γ-carboxyglutamic acid (Gla)-rich domain followed by two epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like domains, and the C-terminal heavy chain contains an activation peptide followed by the catalytic domain with a trypsin-like primary specificity pocket (6Leytus S.P. Foster D.C. Kurachi K. Davie E.W. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 5098-5102Google Scholar, 8Padmanabhan K. Padmanabhan K.P. Tulinsky A. Park C.H. Bode W. Huber R. Blankenship D.T. Cardin A.D. Kisiel W. J. Mol. Biol. 1993; 232: 947-966Google Scholar). FX can be activated by either one of its two physiological activators, the factor VIIa-tissue factor (TF) complex (extrinsic Xase) or the factor IXa-VIIIa complex (intrinsic Xase) on negatively charged membrane surfaces in the presence of Ca2+ (9Morrissey J.H. Fakhrai H. Edgington T.S. Cell. 1987; 50: 129-135Google Scholar, 10Lollar P. Fay P.J. Fass D.N. Methods Enzymol. 1993; 222: 128-143Google Scholar, 11Yoshitake S. Schach B.G. Foster D.C. Davie E.W. Kurachi K. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 3736-3750Google Scholar, 12Mertens K. Celie P.H.N. Kolkman J.A. Lenting P.J. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1999; 82: 209-217Google Scholar). In addition, a specific enzyme from Russell's viper venom (RVV-X) can also efficiently activate FX in the presence of Ca2+ (5Jackson C.M. Nemerson Y. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1980; 49: 765-811Google Scholar, 13Furie B.C. Furie B. Methods Enzymol. 1976; 45: 191-205Google Scholar). All three activators specifically cleave a single peptide bond, Arg15–Ile16 (chymotrypsinogen numbering system (14Bode W. Mayr I. Baumann U. Huber R. Stone S.R. Hofsteenge J. EMBO J. 1989; 8: 3467-3475Google Scholar)), on the activation peptide of FX to generate an active enzyme. Efficient cleavage of this peptide bond by both physiological activators occurs only in the presence of the cofactors because neither factor VIIa nor factor IXa by itself can activate FX at a significant rate. Similar to the cofactor-dependent activation of FX, the catalytic activity of FXa toward its natural substrate prothrombin is also cofactor-dependent. In this case, the high affinity binding of factor Va to FXa in the prothrombinase complex enhances the catalytic efficiency of the protease by greater than 5 orders of magnitude (2Rosing J. Tans G. Govers-Riemslag J.W.P. Zwaal R.F.A. Hemker H.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 274-283Google Scholar, 15Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 5386-5391Google Scholar). The exact mechanism by which cofactors improve the catalytic efficiency of coagulation proteases is not well understood. One possible mechanism is that the binding of the cofactors to their target proteases allosterically changes the conformation of the substrate-binding sites in the catalytic pocket of coagulation enzymes to optimize their interaction with residues near the scissile bonds, particularly those located at the P3–P3′ sites (16Esmon C.T. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1993; 70: 1-5Google Scholar). In support of this hypothesis, a factor VIIIa-mediated conformational change in the active-site pocket of factor IXa has been reported (17Mutucumarana V.P. Duffy E.J. Lollar P. Johnson A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17012-17021Google Scholar). Furthermore, binding of TF to factor VIIa is known to increase significantly the rate of hydrolysis of synthetic tripeptidyl chromogenic substrates (18Neuenschwander P.F. Branam D.E. Morrissey J.H. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1993; 70: 970-977Google Scholar, 19Lawson J.H. Butenas S. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4834-4843Google Scholar). However, it has become clear in recent years that in addition to interaction with the target proteases, cofactors must also interact with the zymogens before they can exert their full physiological effect in coagulation reactions. In support of this, recent kinetic and mutagenesis studies have indicated that factor Va interaction with both FXa and prothrombin is required for efficient thrombin generation by the prothrombinase complex (20Rezaie A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 3320-3327Google Scholar, 21Kalafatis M. Beck D.O. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 12715-12728Google Scholar, 22Anderson P.J. Nesset A. Dharmawardana K.R. Bock P.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 16435-16442Google Scholar, 23Chen L. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 27564-27569Google Scholar, 24Beck D.O. Bukys M.A. Singh L.S. Szabo K.A. Kalafatis M. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 3084-3095Google Scholar). Similarly, in addition to interaction with factor VIIa, TF is also known to interact with FX in order to promote substrate activation by the extrinsic Xase complex (25Ruf W. Miles D.J. Rehemtulla A. Edgington T.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 6375-6381Google Scholar, 26Huang Q. Neuenschwander P.F. Rezaie A.R. Morrissey J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 21752-21757Google Scholar, 27Kirchofer D. Lipari M.T. Moran P. Eigenbrot C. Kelley R.F. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 7380-7387Google Scholar). It is also well established that thrombomodulin binds to both thrombin and protein C in order to enhance the rate of protein C activation by thrombin in the anticoagulant pathway (28Vindigni A. White C.E. Komives E.A. Di Cera E. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 6674-6681Google Scholar, 29Fuentes-Prior P. Iwanaga Y. Huber R. Pagila R. Rumennik G. Seto M. Morser J. Light D.R. Bode W. Nature. 2000; 404: 518-525Google Scholar, 30Yang L. Rezaie A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 10484-10490Google Scholar). It is likely that factor VIIIa also functions by a similar mechanism in the intrinsic Xase complex. The multidomain nature of coagulation proteases and their substrates allows them to interact with each other and with their cofactors with a high degree of specificity to form efficient activation complexes on negatively charged membrane surfaces. Previously, the contribution of Gla and N-terminal EGF (EGF-N) domains of FX/Xa to the recognition specificity of the macromolecular complex assembly has been investigated by several different mutagenesis approaches. Studies with the deletion mutants of FX/Xa lacking either Gla or both Gla and EFG-N domains have indicated that the protease domain of FXa has a binding site for factor Va in the prothrombinase complex (20Rezaie A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 3320-3327Google Scholar, 31Rezaie A.R. Neuenschwander P.F. Morrissey J.H. Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8176-8180Google Scholar). These studies, which were all carried out in solution, also suggested a role for the Gla and/or EGF-N domain of FXa in interaction with the cofactor (31Rezaie A.R. Neuenschwander P.F. Morrissey J.H. Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8176-8180Google Scholar). However, in two other recent studies with a chimeric FXa in which both the Gla and EGF-N domains of the protease were replaced with corresponding domains of factor IX, one study reported that neither Gla nor EGF-N contributes to the affinity of FXa-factor Va interaction on phospholipid vesicles in the prothrombinase complex (32Thiec F. Cherel G. Christophe O.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 10393-10399Google Scholar). Nonetheless, the second study, employing an identical construct, reported that the Gla and/or EGF-N domains of FXa contribute ∼10-fold to the affinity of the cofactor interaction (33Hertzberg M.S. Ben-Tal O. Furie B. Furie B.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14759-14766Google Scholar). The reason for these contradictory results is not known. To investigate further the role of the EGF-N domain of FX/Xa by a different approach, we constructed a deletion mutant of FX in which the exon coding for EGF-N was deleted from FX cDNA. This mutant was expressed in mammalian cells and purified to homogeneity as described (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). Unlike the previous mutant lacking both the Gla and EGF-N (E2-FX) (31Rezaie A.R. Neuenschwander P.F. Morrissey J.H. Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8176-8180Google Scholar), this mutant contains an intact Gla domain; thus, the zymogenic and enzymatic properties of this mutant could be characterized in appropriate activation complexes on phospholipid vesicles. In this study, we present data that suggest that the EGF-N domain of FX is required for the zymogen activation by both the extrinsic and intrinsic Xase complexes. On the other hand, the FXa mutant interacted with factor Va with a similar affinity on phospholipid vesicles and activated prothrombin with ∼3-fold impaired catalytic efficiency. Most interesting, the mutant activated prothrombin with ∼12-fold better catalytic efficiency in the absence of factor Va and exhibited a similar or better specific activity in a one-stage FXa clotting assay, although it was inactive in both PT and aPTT assays. These results suggest an important role for EGF-N in recognition and activation of FX by both physiological activators, but this domain appears not to have a specific role in FXa recognition of factor Va in the prothrombinase complex. The implication of these findings for the spacer function of FX/Xa within the activation complexes is discussed. Mutagenesis and Expression of Recombinant Proteins—Construction and expression of wild-type FX in an expression/purification vector system has been described previously (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). The EGF-N deletion mutant of FX, lacking the exon coding for the N-terminal EGF domain of FX (FX-desEGF-N), was prepared by PCR mutagenesis methods in the same vector system as described (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). After confirmation of the accuracy of the mutagenesis by DNA sequencing, the constructs containing either wild-type or mutant FX cDNA were transfected into HEK293 cells, and the recombinant proteins were isolated from cell culture supernatants by a combination of immunoaffinity and ion exchange chromatography using the HPC4 monoclonal antibody and a Mono Q FPLC column as described (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). Recombinant soluble tissue-factor (sTF) and TF lacking the cytoplasmic domain (dcTF), both purified from bacteria (35Rezaie A.R. Fiore M.M. Neuenschwander P.F. Esmon C.T. Morrissey J.H. Protein Expression Purif. 1992; 3: 453-460Google Scholar, 36Neuenschwander P.F. Bianco-Fisher E. Rezaie A.R. Morrissey J.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 13988-13993Google Scholar), were kindly provided by Dr. James Morrissey (University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign). Human plasma proteins including antithrombin, factors Va, VIIa, IXa, Xa, and X, and the factor X-activating enzyme from RVV-X were purchased from Hematologic Technologies Inc. (Essex Junction, VT). Human factor VIIIa was a generous gift from Dr. Philip Fay (University of Rochester, New York). Phospholipid vesicles containing 80% phosphatidylcholine and 20% phosphatidylserine (PC/PS) were prepared as described (37Smirnov M.D. Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 816-819Google Scholar). The incorporation of dcTF into PC/PS vesicles has been described previously (36Neuenschwander P.F. Bianco-Fisher E. Rezaie A.R. Morrissey J.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 13988-13993Google Scholar). The chromogenic substrate Spectrozyme FXa (SpFXa) was purchased from American Diagnostica (Greenwich, CT), and S2238 was purchased from Kabi Pharmacia/Chromogenix (Franklin, OH). PT (Thrombomax with Ca2+) and aPTT (Alexin) reagents were purchased from Sigma. Normal pooled plasma and factor X-deficient plasma from a genetically deficient patient were purchased from George King Bio-Medical, Inc. (Overland Park, KS). Activation by the Factors IXa-VIIIa Complex—The initial rate of concentration dependence of FX activation by factor IXa on PC/PS vesicles was studied in both the absence and presence of factor VIIIa as described (38Chen L. Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Protein Sci. 2004; 13: 431-442Google Scholar). Briefly, the activation of increasing concentrations of the wild-type and mutant FX (7.8–1000 nm) by factor IXa (50 nm in the absence and 0.025–1.0 nm in the presence of factor VIIIa) on PC/PS vesicles (70 μm) was monitored in the absence or presence of a saturating concentration of factor VIIIa (25 nm)in0.1 m NaCl, 0.02 m Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, containing 0.1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, 0.1% PEG 8000, and 5 mm Ca2+ (TBS/Ca2+) for 2–90 min at room temperature in 30-μl reactions in 96-well assay plates. The activation reactions were terminated by an addition of 20 μl of EDTA to a final concentration of 20 mm, and the rate of FXa generation was determined by an amidolytic activity assay from the cleavage of 50 μl of 0.4 mm SpFXa at 405 nm by a Vmax Kinetic Microplate Reader (Molecular Devices, Menlo Park, CA). It was ensured that less than 10% of FX was activated at all substrate concentrations. The Km and kcat values for the activation reactions were calculated from the Michaelis-Menten equation. Activation by the Factor VIIa-TF Complex—The initial rate of concentration dependence of FX activation on PC/PS vesicles was studied in both the absence and presence of sTF and dcTF incorporated into PC/PS vesicles as described (35Rezaie A.R. Fiore M.M. Neuenschwander P.F. Esmon C.T. Morrissey J.H. Protein Expression Purif. 1992; 3: 453-460Google Scholar, 36Neuenschwander P.F. Bianco-Fisher E. Rezaie A.R. Morrissey J.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 13988-13993Google Scholar). Briefly, the activation of increasing concentrations of the wild-type and mutant FX (7.8–2600 nm) by factor VIIa (20 nm in the absence of and 0.025–1.0 nm in the presence of TF) was monitored in the absence or presence of a saturating concentration of sTF (250 nm) and relipidated dcTF (2 nm) in TBS/Ca2+ for 1–30 min at room temperature in 30-μl reactions in 96-well assay plates. The activation reactions were terminated by an addition of 20 μl of EDTA to obtain a final concentration of 20 mm. The concentration of FXa generated was determined from standard curves by a chromogenic substrate assay as described above. The Km and kcat values for the activation reactions were calculated as described above. Activation by RVV-X and Amidolytic Activity—To evaluate the catalytic properties of the FXa mutant, 500 μl of 2 μm wild-type or mutant zymogen was incubated with 20 nm RVV-X in TBS/Ca2+ for 2 h at 37 °C. To separate the snake venom, the activation reactions were individually applied on a heparin-Sepharose column, and following extensive washes with TBS/Ca2+ containing 0.2 m NaCl, activated proteins were eluted with the same buffer containing 0.5 m NaCl as described previously (20Rezaie A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 3320-3327Google Scholar). Active fractions were pooled and reapplied to the HPC4 monoclonal antibody column that was used to purify both wild-type and mutant zymogens. The HPC4 antibody recognized a 12-residue epitope engineered to the N-terminal end of the activation peptide; thus, activated FX does not bind to the column (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). Because the zymogen FX binds to the column, the flow-through of this purification step contains only activated protein. Thus, both unbound wild-type and mutant FXa from the HPC4 column were pooled, concentrated, and active-site titrated by stoichiometric titrations with known concentrations of antithrombin as described (38Chen L. Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Protein Sci. 2004; 13: 431-442Google Scholar). The steady-state kinetics of hydrolysis of SpFXa (7.8–1000 μm) by the wild-type and mutant FXa (1 nm) were studied in TBS/Ca2+, and the Km and kcat values for substrate hydrolysis were calculated from the Michaelis-Menten equation as described above. Activation of Prothrombin—The initial rate of prothrombin activation by the wild-type and mutant FXa was determined in both the absence and presence of factor Va at room temperature on PC/PS vesicles as described (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). In the absence of the cofactor, prothrombin (10–2500 nm) was incubated with either wild-type or mutant FXa (2.5 nm) in TBS/Ca2+ on PC/PS vesicles (35 μm). Following 5 min of incubation at room temperature, the rate of thrombin generation was measured by an amidolytic activity assay using 100 μm S2238. The concentrations of thrombin generated in the activation reactions were determined from a standard curve prepared from the cleavage rate of S2238 by known concentrations of thrombin under exactly the same conditions. The initial rate of prothrombin activation in the presence of human factor Va (25 nm) was measured by incubating each FXa derivative (25–100 pm) with increasing concentrations of prothrombin (7.8–1000 nm) in TBS/Ca2+ on PC/PS vesicles (35 μm). Following 0.5–2 min of incubation at room temperature, EDTA was added to a final concentration of 20 mm, and the concentration of thrombin generated was determined from a standard curve as described above. It was ensured that less than 15% of prothrombin was activated at all concentrations of the substrate. The cofactor dependence of prothrombin activation by FXa was also used to evaluate the apparent affinity of factor Va for the wild-type and mutant FXa. In this case, the activation of a fixed concentration of prothrombin (1 μm) by wild-type or mutant FXa (100 pm) was monitored in the presence of increasing concentrations of human factor Va (0.3–20 nm) on PC/PS vesicles (35 μm). The activation reactions were carried out at room temperature for 0.5–2 min after which EDTA was added to a final concentration of 20 mm, and the apparent dissociation constants were determined from the cofactor-dependent rate of thrombin generation as described (20Rezaie A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 3320-3327Google Scholar). The same assay was also used to evaluate the apparent affinity of FXa derivatives for interaction with PC/PS vesicles. In this case, the activation of prothrombin or prethrombin-1 (prothrombin lacking both Gla and kringle-1 domains) (1 μm) by FXa (0.1–1 nm) in complex with a limiting fixed concentration of factor Va (0.4 nm) was monitored in the presence of increasing concentrations of PC/PS vesicles (0–5 μm) for 1–15 min, and the apparent dissociation constants were determined from the PC/PS-dependent rate of thrombin generation as described above. Measurement of Clotting Activities—Clotting activities of the wild-type and mutant FX were determined by PT, aPTT, and one-stage FXa clotting assays by using a STart 4 fibrinometer (Diagnostica/Stago, Asnieres, France) as described (38Chen L. Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Protein Sci. 2004; 13: 431-442Google Scholar). For measuring the prothrombin time (PT), 0.1 ml of the PT reagent containing Ca2+ was added to a mixture of 0.05 ml of the test sample (human plasma, recombinant wild-type, or deletion mutant of FX) and 0.05 ml of FX-deficient plasma at 37 °C. Activities of test samples were calculated from a standard curve made by using four different dilutions of normal pooled plasma ranging from 0.1 to 0.025 unit/ml (1 unit/ml corresponds to 8 μg/ml FX). In the case of aPTT assay, 0.050 ml of aPTT reagent was incubated with a mixture of 0.05 ml of FX-deficient plasma and 0.05 ml of the test samples for 5 min before the initiation of clotting by the addition of 0.05 ml of 35 mm CaCl2 at 37 °C. For the one-stage FXa clotting assay, 0.05 ml of 0.05–0.4 nm FXa or FXa-desEGF-N was incubated with 0.05 ml of plasma and 0.05 ml of PC/PS vesicles (10 μg/ml). Clotting was initiated at 37 °C by the addition of 0.05 ml of 25 mm CaCl2. The clotting activities of samples were calculated from at least four dilutions that yielded clotting times in the linear range of the standard curves (17–35 s for PT, 44–64 s for aPTT, and 41–90 s for the one-stage FXa clotting assay). Expression and Purification of Recombinant Proteins—Both the wild-type and mutant FX were expressed in human 293 cells as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Recombinant proteins were separated from the cell culture supernatants by immunoaffinity chromatography using the HPC4 monoclonal antibody as described previously (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar). Further purification on a Mono Q column was required to separate the fully and partially γ-carboxylated proteins as described (34Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6780-6788Google Scholar, 38Chen L. Manithody C. Yang L. Rezaie A.R. Protein Sci. 2004; 13: 431-442Google Scholar). SDS-PAGE analysis of the purified proteins in both zymogen and active forms under nonreducing conditions indicated that both recombinant FX and the mutant have been purified to homogeneity (data not shown). The wild-type and mutant FX zymogens migrated with the expected relative molecular masses of ∼60 and ∼55 kDa and following activation with the expected molecular masses of ∼45 and ∼40 kDa, respectively (data not shown). FX Activation by the Intrinsic Xase Complex—The zymogenic properties of wild-type and mutant FX were evaluated in kinetic studies by factor IXa in both the absence and presence of factor VIIIa and Ca2+ on PC/PS vesicles (intrinsic Xase complex). The concentration dependence of the activation reactions suggested that factor IXa by itself activates both FX derivatives with similar kcat values; however, Km(app) for activation of the mutant was elevated ∼10-fold (Fig. 1A and Table I). Most interesting, a similar ∼10-fold impairment in the Km(app) value with the mutant was also observed in the presence of factor VIIIa (Fig. 1B and Table I). However, unlike the similar kcat values in the absence of factor VIIIa, the kcat value for the activation of the mutant was also impaired nearly 20-fold (Fig. 1B and Table I). These results suggest that the catalytic efficiency of the intrinsic Xase complex toward the activation of the FX mutant has been impaired ∼200-fold. Thus, the N-terminal domain of FX plays a crucial role in substrate activation by factor IXa in both the absence and presence of the cofactor. A previous study (33Hertzberg M.S. Ben-Tal O. Furie B. Furie B.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14759-14766Google Scholar) with a chimeric FX mutant that contained the Gla and EGF-N domains of factor IX demonstrated that neither domain of FX contributed to recognition of the protease or the cofactor in the intrinsic Xase complex. Thus, by assuming that EGF-N of factor IX in the chimeric molecule did not functionally substitute for a potential interactive site of FX in the intrinsic Xase complex, the results here would implicate an important spacer function for EGF-N in FX activation by the intrinsic Xase complex.Table IKinetic parameters for the activation of wild-type and mutant FX zymogens by factors VIIa and IXa in the absence and presence of cofactors on PC/PS vesiclesFXFX-desEGF-NKm(app)kcatKm(app)kcatnms-1nms-1Factor VIIa, PC/PS626 ± 80(2.0 ± 0.1) × 10-4470 ± 53(1.6 ± 0.1) × 10-4Factor VIIa, PC/PS, dcTF55 ± 94.4 ± 0.21035 ± 160(2.0 ± 0.1) × 10-2Factor VIIa, PC/PS, sTF14 ± 3(3.7 ± 0.2) × 10-22313 ± 502(2.1 ± 0.3) × 10-4Factor IXa, PC/PS132 ± 7(2.8 ± 0.2) × 10-51248 ± 185(4.0 ± 0.3) × 10-5Factor IXa, PC/PS, FVIIIa27 ± 22.0 ± 0.03257 ± 140.11 ± 0.002 Open table in a new tab Activation by the Extrinsic Xase Complex—The zymogenic properties of the FX mutant were also evaluated in kinetic studies by factor VIIa in both the absence and presence of TF and Ca2+ on PC/PS vesicles (extrinsic Xase complex). In the absence of a cofactor, factor VIIa activated both wild-type and mutant FX with a similar catalytic efficiency on PC/PS vesicles (Fig. 2, A, inset, and B, and Table I). Consistent with previous results, sTF dramatically accelerated the activation of wild-type FX by factor VIIa (Fig. 2A). Most interesting, however, sTF negatively affected the activation of FX-desEGF-N by factor VIIa as evidenced by an ∼5-fold elevated Km(app) in the presence of the cofactor (Fig. 2B). With the relipidated TF, relative to activation of wild-type FX (Fig. 3A), the catalytic efficiency of factor VIIa toward FX-desEGF-N was impaired more than 4200-fold (Fig. 3B and Table I). Unlike sTF, relipidated TF improved the catalytic efficiency of factor VIIa toward the FX mutant ∼100-fold (compare Figs. 2B and 3B). The dramatic impairment in activation of the mutant was caused by an ∼19-fold elevated Km(app) and ∼220-fold decreased kcat values (Table I). These results suggest that the N-terminal EGF domain of FX plays a critical role in FX activation by the extrinsic Xase complex. The observation that factor VIIa in the absence of a cofactor activates both wild-type and mutant FX at similar rates, further suggests that EGF-N does not interact with the protease but interacts with the cofactor and/or has a spacer function in the extrinsic Xase complex (see below).Fig. 3Concentration dependence of wild-type and mutant FX activation by factor VIIa in complex with relipidated dcTF. A, factor VIIa (25 pm) in complex with the relipidated dcTF (2 nm) was incubated with different concentrations of wild-type FX (○) in TBS/Ca2+.
